block.para:
Earlier we already discussed
linear transformations \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m]
Look up this definition
. So what is new here?
Indeed, the formal properties defined for a linear map \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m] are the exact same as those for a linear map L\from V\to W:

li.para: L must commute with vector addition: L(\Vect{x}+\Vect{y}) = L(\Vect{x}) + L(\Vect{y}).
L must commute with scalar multiplication: L(t\cdot \Vect{x}) = t\cdot L(\Vect{x}).

block.para: New here is merely that the vector spaces V and W need not be equal to \RNr[n] and \RNr[m]. Instead, any subvector space is allowed.

Comment on a technicality When we require V and W to be subvector space of \RNr[k], at first sight, it would seem more appropriate to let V be a subvector space of \RNr[p] and to let W be a subvector space of \RNr[q]. However, we can take k to be the maximum of p and q, and so both Vand W appear as subspaces of the same vector space \RNr[k].

Outlook In a more advanced setting, we will liberate ourselves from the requirement that V and W be subsets of any other vector space. Instead, we will just assume that a vector space is an algebraic object in which one may operate ‘as if one were inside some \RNr[n]’.
